If the Democrats could just reshape that because it created so many rifts between gender, race, sexuality, sports fans, entertainment choices, wherever there are liberals, there's division. So what they could do, the idea of America as a family, right? That all different kinds of families. Families could be any kind of family, but we're all in this together. That would be basically taking Trump's vision and moving it a step further. If they actually believed in that, they would do two things. They've separate themselves from identity politics, which people are tired of. And two, they have a winning message.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I'm just so struck because I have such a different view.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Well, sorry, Juan. It's going to have to wait.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Big (INAUDIBLE) by President Trump, he's ordering hundreds of troops to the southern border as the caravan pushes north. That's next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: President Trump telling the massive caravan heading north through Mexico to turn around. This is -- he's sending signals, at least 800 troops will be arriving at the southern border to help stop the migrants. Trump is also continuing to use the issue to pound Democrats.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: As we speak, the Democrat Party is openly encouraging caravan after caravan of illegal aliens to violate our laws and break into our country. Right now, it's the sole result of Democrat laws and activist Democrat judges that do whatever they want. And that prevent us from returning illegal aliens back home to Central America and other parts of the world.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. So, let me start with Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here he is, we've been talking about, you know, can he tone it down a little bit, given what's going on with the bombings and everything. And here he is saying, oh, Democrats are encouraging the caravan. I think, previously, some were saying, oh, George Soros might be paying them. Democrats are encouraging them, activist judges. Is this fair?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it is fair when any time a person brings up kind of a logical argument about the consequences of waiving a caravan through, they're called bigots or xenophobic or racist. So, in that way, by scaring people and not actually saying the logical consequences, I do think that helps. The troops, though, are telling you something very clear. This is not happening. The caravan is destined to fail. So those feeding this spectacle with cameras and emotional testimony, they're not helping anybody. You think you care, but you're actually driving a caravan that's expanding and multiplying because, essentially, you're saying keep going. Keep going. They're going to meet an army. It's not going to happen. And this is -- for the Democrats, this is what happens when your ideas are brought to a logical conclusion, complete with visual.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And so, Dana, the fact that there's still more than a thousand miles away, we already have 2100 troops on the border. Trump is talking about sending 800 more to help the homeland security.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, part of it -- he wants to send troops to the border not just to deal with the caravan, but the fact that regardless of the caravan, like last week we were told by the commissioner for the border patrol, 640 illegal crossings attempted a day. So it's not just for the caravan, which is a thousand miles away. It is for this push that keeps coming. Politically, if you look at Senator Donnelly and Senator McCaskill, red state Democrats, they're in states where President Trump won by plus 20, this is not the issue that they want to deal with. And conventional wisdom in Washington, D.C. would tell you it is not good if you're a Democrat to bring up immigration and be tough on the border. But what's happening in the southwest, Dean Heller, who is the most vulnerable senate Republican, he's now plus 6 in a Reuters' poll. McSally is starting to pull away in Arizona. So the Democrats -- when we're talking about the blue wave, the house may be one thing, but the senate looks like it is increasingly out of reach. And I think that -- what Kavanaugh being one, the economy being another, Trump being out there and campaigning for them, but you can't discount the fact that immigration is still an issue that people want to vote on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think Republicans want to vote on it. I think it's number one for Republicans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In some states.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . not for Democrat -- in some states, what do you mean by that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because health care is still one of the number one issue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think for Democrats and for independents, health care is the number one issue. But I think for some Republicans, immigration. And so, Jesse, this brings me to you. It looks like the president is pushing a culture war, fear-type issue in order to stir his base.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you've been repeating that same argument for a month. It doesn't make it right. I don't think there's anything he's doing to stoke a culture war. He's just saying we have a country with borders that need to be protected against people that think they have a right to just come across willy-nilly. I have a press release from the people that are running the show, people without borders, this is not a local group. This is a third-party group. You know what they say, they're demanding respect for, quote, the international right to migrate. So anybody anywhere can walk across the border of any country and they have a right to do that. Think about that. As Dana knows, the treaty of Westphalia established the concept of the nation states. And we saw what happened in Europe, when all these Syrian refugees flew across to the E.U. and it caused absolute chaos. Even now, Merkel is regretting that decision. And people are building walls. And you have Brexit. So that backfired big-time. George W. Bush sent National Guard to the border. Barack Obama sent 1200 National Guard to the border. Sometimes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, I thought a minute ago you said the Democrats want open borders.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it was causing him such political problems that he had to go deal with people that were coming across with children.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Imagine that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Remember, that was when he was also separating children from their families.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Pam, let me turn to you because today's reporting on the news is about how, in fact, the caravan looks to begetting smaller, because people are suffering exhaustion -- heat exhaustion, dehydration. And, you know, they don't -- they're still walking.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Well, I hope the mothers with the babies that you've seen, and there aren't that many of them, thank goodness, have turned around and gone back. Because somebody is feeding them a line if they think they're going to get into our country, because they're not. So I hope they've gone home. Let me tell you, from a prosecutor's point of view, Juan. The last case I was working on before I ran for attorney general, the last case, it was a car carrier from Mexico coming into our country. And in the pipes that carried the cars, resistant to dog sniffing. Stuffed full of kilos of cocaine and assault rifles, from Mexico and we stopped it in Florida. That's why we have to protect our borders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What highway is that again?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey, you can't go there. Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He has a right to migrate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do have a --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right to migrate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: White line fever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. But you know what I can't stand is all the phony stuff online that, it seems to me make the caravan out to be, like, an army approaching. I just don't think that's real.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think the visuals tell the story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What about the visuals?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what the A.P. said, Juan? They called it a ragtag army of the poor. That was the A.P. that said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's -- "the poor" is the operative word there. It's not "army."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was going to go ragtag army.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You like that better. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The A.P. did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse wins. Brown University taking on so-called toxic masculinity with a new course, and we've got the man to give you the details right here on THE FIVE, straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the phrase you hear these days from dopes pretending to be smart: "toxic masculinity."

utterances.speaker: The gist
utterances.utterance: masculinity is poison. Forget the great achievements that took great risk on the part of men and even resulted in their deaths. No, man are violent, sex-mad animals. And so Brown University offers a course aimed at unlearning toxic masculinity. We used to call this "Basket Weaving 101." If you're willing to give brown 50 grand for this crap, you need to unlearn common sense, too. Besides, it makes no sense. I mean, if men are so toxic, why would you want them detoxing on your campus?

utterances.speaker: My prediction
utterances.utterance: unlearning toxic masculinity will soon be replacing Western Civ. After all, there's no question men are more aggressive than women. It's science. And it doesn't hurt to civilize unruly cads. That's what dads and moms used to do before we decided they sucked. And men do live shorter lives. Just look at me. But mainly because of the risks taken to attract and protect the people we love. But if you believe this is about appreciating men while terming away the rough parts, you kid yourself. This is pure class hatred based on stereotypes meant to demean a group of people. It's the branding of a gender by angry, bitter radicals. It's also sexist. If you don't believe me, just create your own class for Brown and call it "Unlearning Toxic femininity." How long do you think that will last? Well, then again, maybe it's in the works already, designed to focus on those horrible, toxic stay-at-home moms who voted for Trump. All right, Dana, let's say you're at Brown, which I believe is a university. And you -- would you date a guy who is taking a --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Never. No, it's not even a question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know, we do these stories about date -- remember dating tips?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you've had "Gutfeld's Dating Tips." Nowhere on any dating tip should you be taking this class. Nowhere. I think a better test would be for men from Brown to have to go work on a ranch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: For like a month.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I'm saying that as someone who couldn't work on a ranch.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They would take you, though, at home, back home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can -- I could use ranch --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They would love to have you come visit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, it would end badly. Juan, are you filled with toxic masculinity? Are you a toxic male?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Could you use the class?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Actually, Pam, I think I could use the class. Because it seems to me you, you know, the male need to be dominant and the way that we look at sex and the interaction, I -- things have puzzled me throughout my life. Like, for example -- this is --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Explain that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Go back, like you know --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's get deep.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you one, Jesse. Because you know, you're a guy, too. I just -- but like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tell me, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- the O.J. Simpson case, I could never understand why a woman would go back to a guy that was beating her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It just was puzzling to me. And then I heard from other people, "Oh, no, that's not unusual."

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Classic D.V.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's nuts. And my niece is a prosecutor in D.C., and she tells me people come from some countries, and they'll say, "Oh, yes, that's the way men act. Men hit women." I'm like, "What? Where is that from? How is that a defense?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know if O.J. is what they mean when they say toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You do? I don't know if that's what they mean.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he's just called a murderer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think you should go survey the class, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, I have a very long history at Brown. The last time I was shooting a "Watters' World" there, a guy with a skirt chased me around and heckled me the whole time. They hate me up there. It's because I'm so toxic. I think that's really what it is.

utterances.speaker: But I agree with Dana. I've always been under the assumption that women are attracted to men that are manly
utterances.utterance: that make a lot of money, that work with their hands, that sweep you off your feet, that hold the door for you, take care of you and act tough. You know, don't cry. Never show their feelings.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, yes. That's not exactly --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's exactly what Dana said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, speak up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to let Pam speak for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pam, do you think this is -- this feels like a reeducation camp for the evil male to me. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Well, as an employer, as a grad school, can you imagine looking at transcripts, seeing "Unleashing Toxic Masculinity"? what grade did you get? If you didn't get an "A," you're going to be in big trouble, taking that class.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: First of all, this needs to be learned, obviously, much younger in the home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: If you're in college and you still have these issues, you shouldn't be there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And by the way, the issues are they just don't like men. So they do this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: At Brown, don't you think that guys sign up for this class thinking that they're going to get a date?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK? And they might get a date.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The undercover toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But do you want to date a woman who's interested in taking the toxic masculinity --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You want to date any woman in college! They'll take any course.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. And women at Brown probably want them to take that class, and then they can talk about it and things like that. But I don't think it will last.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think so either. But it's now -- the new thing is to call it toxic. It's like if you said this about women, your toxic femininity, you would be -- you would probably be fired.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You should write that article tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: "Toxic Femininity." I think it would be great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What would be the symptoms, Dana, of toxic femininity?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We talk about them all the time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do we?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, really? All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Cheese.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, cheese now. All right. An absurd new fashion trend and much more up next in "Fastest Seven."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's fun music.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for "The Fastest Seven." First up, chewing gum etiquette. BEN STEIN, ACTOR/COMMENTATOR: As of this point, this is very controversial. Does anyone know what Vice President Bush called this in 1980? Anyone?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A dispute over a noisy package of gum led to a brawl at a classical music concert in Sweden. Apparently, one concertgoer thought the lady next to him was being too loud with their gum and tossed it across the room, prompting her to slap him across the face. This seems like something you would get involved in, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, 100 percent totally justified.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sorry. I --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Both of you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Three days ago -- this almost happened to me today. I had to go to the eye doctor. Everyone should go to the eye doctor. And I was getting my -- just getting a little tea to take upstairs to my appointment. And this woman next to me had her headphones in, and she had this bag, and she was eating a croissant. But she was taking little bites and crinkling the paper the entire time. And she couldn't hear it, because she had her earphones in. And I thought of this woman who was chewing her gum at the concert. You can't do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just want the audience to know, when my phone dings during the show, Dana, like, shoots daggers at me. She's very auditory sensitive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Peter and I haven't gone to the movies in 15 years because of this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, really.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: God, what a lucky man.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You haven't missed much, all right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what this tells you, though? Heated rhetoric holds nothing compared to proximity.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's, like, all about the proximity of an annoyance. For example, if somebody told you you could punch somebody in the face with no consequence for somebody 300 miles away for crinkling a bag, you'd go "Why?" But if it's somebody next to you on the subway, you'd go, "Hell yes!"

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If somebody told you to turn your headphones down on a plane.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why the media is so angry all the time, because they live in Manhattan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they're all like this all the time, rising the subway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Proximity creates all hostility.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's how wars happen. I made that up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. That's why you have a very large estate somewhere that no one knows about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's why everybody in Kansas is happy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought your facts were off, because as I read the story --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He was -- they were opening -- she was opening a brand-new package of gum. And you know, at some level you can --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It was crinkling, and they're at a concert.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I think, yes. So I mean, I would tolerate, because I think --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you're in a concert. It's music. But I would tolerate someone just opening a Lifesavers or something. But a whole package and making a big deal out of it, come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're supposed to drink champagne at something like that, not chew gum. So gauche. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: I think Juicy Fruit should uses it: the gum worth fighting for.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ooh, I like that. That's a good idea.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: We should get part of that royalty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. I want a part of the check.

utterances.speaker: Next up, the new bizarre winter fashion trend. Nose warmers. A British company getting a lot of attention for a lin of products that promise to keep your nose nice and toasty this winner. The question is
utterances.utterance: would you actually wear one of these things? I mean, I might wear one but probably not with the leopard print.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I -- look, I can see where they're going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I think it's better to have, like, the whole, like, half face mask thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Looks like Rudolph.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't think I would do this. But I understand. I mean, when your nose is cold, like mine is right now because it's freezing in the studio, I could see why you'd want it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is a prank. They're wearing a thong. They're wearing the Chippendale's dancers' thong right now. By the way, I have a nose warmer. It's called my finger.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, I believe this is for --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- coke heads. That's what it's for. For coke heads to hide their missing septums.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Smart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Brits do love the coke. I didn't ask. Doesn't -- I'm not going to bring it up. All right, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well I mean, the thing about it, like, you know the problem here is if you were an Eskimo, how would you kiss, because they kiss with their noses?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a problem. Hadn't thought it all the way through.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Translate that brilliant analogy to politics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I'd say, doesn't that thing look like a bra?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You and Gutfeld. Really. Get your mind out of the gutter, guys.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But look at it. It's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pam doesn't even know what we're talking about. It's, like, never this cold in Florida.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Well, I know. I would say, I hope they come with pumpkin spice scent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a nice idea.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Medium-size, and with sunscreen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nobody would wear them.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Sunscreen. Sunscreen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think this is a fake story.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did we just get hoaxed?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think we might have.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's on my segment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And finally with Halloween, less than a week away, FiveThirtyEight.com is using its polling prowess to come up with the ultimate Halloween candy power ranking.

utterances.speaker: The overall winners
utterances.utterance: Reese's peanut butter cups.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With Reese's Minis second and Twix, Kit Kats and Snickers rounding out the top five. All right. So this, I guess, this is the No. 1 candy in America. Do we all agree, or do we disagree.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, 100 percent. You know, the brits also like Reese's peanut butter cups.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They do. They have great taste.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They snort them. They have them with their cocaine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey, wait a second.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Reese's and coke.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Everybody agreed that Reese's peanut butter cups is No. 1?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What about Snickers? I think that's the No. 1?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're up there, Juan. You've got to read the packet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not No. 1.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You were saying the No. 1?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's top five.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you ever have somebody in your neighborhood, on trick-or- treat, that they didn't have candy; and they would, like, give you spare change?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I thought that was weird, and then I realized that that -- I'm that person. Because I don't have kids, so I just totally space on Halloween. And all of a sudden, the doorbell rings; and there's these, like, short creatures screaming at you. So you have to run around --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, why did you come out of the basement?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I give them Campbell's Soup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't eat Campbell's Soup.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I give them cans of Campbell's Soup. I give them socks, anything that's around my house.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You give it away.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The socks would probably fit the kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm the kind of guy that gives, like, the big jumbo size. I'm a really good candy giver.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what's great --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What's your address, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what was great about this list, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maxine is going to come over and yell at me if you tell her. What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They said the worst candies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What are they?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What are the worst candies?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So the worst candy, it turns out, was to give a kid circus peanuts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I was surprised at No. 2, which was candy corn. I thought - -

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like candy corn.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: I like candy corn.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the worst. But the -- but how Mary Jane's? I remember, when I was a kid, those things get stuck in your teeth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Those are no good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, right. But here's --

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: I hate those.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Circus peanuts, you've got to be really careful when you say it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was disappointed that Tootsie Rolls was also on the worst candy list.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I could see that, though. You've got to go to the dentist --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about Sugar Daddies?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like Sugar Daddies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean the suckers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The babies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What about Twix?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you angered Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is the second sexual reference in the same segment. Just keep that in mind. What do we think about Twix?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Small Twixes are disappointing. You've got to have a big Twix. The small ones, they're too small.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I also like a Kit Kat. You can make those last.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Am I the only one who's going to eat candy during this segment?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll take a Kit Kat, please.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Here we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm on a no-sugar diet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is up next. We're going to give Dana a Kit Kat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those are great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So we're fresh back from Texas. We had the barbecue, as you guys saw the other day. We loved it, but it's creating a little bit of a controversy. Who has the best barbecue in America? A lot of competition out there, so my buddy Brian Parker, sports agent to the stars, sent us some ribs from Charlie Virgo's Rendezvous in Memphis, Tennessee. And this place is so good, Gutfeld finished the entire plate in the break before. It's gone. I ate them for lunch. Greg probably had seven of them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Eight. I think I had eight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This place serves a lot of stars. Justin Timberlake has been there, the Rolling Stones.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not going there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: George W. Bush.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Prince William and Harry, and now Greg Gutfeld, another star, loves the ribs from Rendezvous. Thank you guys very much! We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's so nice. Hey, Bri. Go ahead, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So love knows no language. Take a look at this elementary school group in Tennessee, wishing their deaf custodian a very happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The custodian, James Anthony, as you can see, was overcome with emotion. He's been at the school more than 20 years. Sometimes he makes friends with the kids by offering them tips on how to use sign language. Assistant Principal Katie Crabtree said the students have a tough time understanding Anthony, but he's possibly the most popular person in the whole school because his special nonverbal relationship really takes the kids to a different level in their lives. What a wonderful story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's so great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a great job to have, if you're a deaf custodian.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you don't have to listen to the kids.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Listen to them. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They love him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you know how smart dogs are?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, jeez.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Smart.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This smart. Check out this pup. So she pretends to be a stray, and she goes to the local McDonald's and asks customers to give them her burgers. Her name is Princess. So she was caught at McDonald's by her owner, who claimed that the devious dog sometimes sneaks out at night to wander near McDonald's, waiting for customers to pass her scraps while they're in the drive-through lane. And she captured the video by -- the video was captured and Princess was seen approaching a car, and the driver passes her some food. Then she goes to the next car, but it's her owner, so she turns around and goes to the car behind her, because she knows she's not going to get any food. So the owner put a statement on Facebook, asking patrons, "Please don't feed the mischievous dog. She's not a stray. She does actually get fed." And they want to keep her around for a long time. Dogs are pretty smart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it figured out what works.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Would you arrest her?

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: Of course not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Of course not.

utterances.speaker: BONDI
utterances.utterance: I'd feed her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg, you're next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
